case_name: Lonand Grampanchayat v. Respondent No. 1 (on behalf of 36 employees)

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 87 of 1966 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 87 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 20, 1963 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 1886 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 20, 1963 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 1886 of 1963.

facts.text: On March 19, 1963 respondent No. 1 on behalf of 36 employees of the Lonand Grampanchayat applied to the Authority appointed under s. 20(1) of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948 for a direction upon the Grampanchayat to pay overtime wages and damages.

anchor.surface_text: On March 19, 1963 respondent No. 1 on behalf of 36 employees of the Lonand Grampanchayat applied to the Authority appointed under s. 20 1  of the.

facts.text: A number of employees claimed overtime wages from October 23, 1960 for a period of two years two months, and nine days.

anchor.surface_text: A number of employees claimed overtime wages from October 23, 1960 for a period of two years two months, and nine days.

facts.text: One employee claimed wages for a period of seven years and nine months.

anchor.surface_text: One employee claimed wages for a period of seven years and nine months, one claimed wages for six years and ten months

facts.text: One employee claimed wages for six years and ten months.

anchor.surface_text: one claimed wages for six years and ten months and another claimed wages for three years.

facts.text: Another employee claimed wages for three years.

anchor.surface_text: and another claimed wages for three years. By an order dated September 18, 1963 the Authority held

facts.text: By an order dated September 18, 1963 the Authority held that the application should be entertained in respect of the claims for the period subsequent to January 1, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated September 18, 1963 the Authority held that the application should be entertained in respect of the claims for the period subsequent to January 1, 1961

facts.text: The Authority held that employees had sufficient cause for not making the application within the prescribed period of six months prior to January 1, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: as the employees had sufficient cause for number making the application within the prescribed period of six months.

facts.text: A petition challenging this order under Art. 227 of the Constitution was summarily dismissed by the Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: A petition challenging this order under Art. 227 of the Constitution was summarily dismissed by the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: From the order of the High Court, the present appeal has been filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: From the order of the High Court, the present appeal has been filed by special leave.

facts.text: On January 2, 1961 the employees wrote to the Inspector, Minimum Wages, government labour office, Sangli, complaining of overtime work and asking for directions on the appellant to comply with the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act.

anchor.surface_text: On January 2, 1961 the employees wrote to the Inspector, Minimum Wages, government labour office, Sangli, companyplaining of overtime work and asking for directions on the appellant to companyply with the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act.

facts.text: A reminder was sent to the Inspector on January 11, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: A reminder was sent to him on January 11, 1961.

facts.text: On January 18, 1961 the Inspector wrote that the matter was being followed up.

anchor.surface_text: On January 18, 1961 the Inspector wrote that the matter was being followed up.

facts.text: On April 22, 1961 the Inspector visited Lonand and directed the appellant to comply with the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act and the rules made thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: On April 22, 1961 the Inspector visited Lonand and directed the appellant to companyply with the provisions of the Minimum Wages Act and the rules made -thereunder.

facts.text: On April 26, 1961 the Inspector communicated this direction to the employees.

anchor.surface_text: On April 26, 1961 the Inspector companymunicated this direction to the employees.

facts.text: On January 1, 1962 the employees lodged a complaint of overtime work with the Commissioner, Poona Division, and asked for a direction for payment of the arrears of overtime wages.

anchor.surface_text: On January 1, 1962 the employees lodged a companyplaint of- overtime work with the Commissioner, Poona Division, and asked for a direction for payment of the arrears of overtime wages.

facts.text: On January 3, 1962 the Commissioner wrote to the employees that the matter was receiving attention and their application had been sent to the Collector of Satara for disposal.

anchor.surface_text: On January 3, 1962 the Commissioner wrote to the employees that the matter was receiving attention and their application had been sent to the, Collector of Satara for disposal.

facts.text: Later in August September 1962 and early 1963 the Block Development Officer came to Lonand and made inquiries.

facts.text: The Authority declined to condone the delay in respect of claims for the period prior to January 1, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The Authority declined to companydone the delay in respect of claims for the period prior to January 1, 1961.

facts.text: The Authority condoned the delay in respect of claims subsequent to January 1, 1961 only.

anchor.surface_text: On a careful companysideration of the relevant materials, the Authority companydoned the delay in respect of claims subsequent to January 1, 1961 only.

facts.text: The employees relied upon the assurances of the inspectors and their superiors that proper steps would be taken for the remedy of their grievances.

anchor.surface_text: The employees relied upon the assurances of the inspectors and their superiors that proper steps would, be taken for the remedy of their grievances and relying upon those assurances, they refrained from taking steps under s 20 2  of the Minimum.Wages Act

facts.text: The appeal is dismissed.

issues.text: Whether the Authority was justified in condoning the delay under the second proviso to s. 20(2) of the Minimum Wages Act in respect of claims for overtime wages subsequent to January 1, 1961 on the ground of sufficient cause

anchor.surface_text: By an order dated September 18, 1963 the Authority held that the application should be entertained in respect of the claims for the period subsequent to January 1, 1961 as the employees had sufficient cause for number making the application within the prescribed period of six months. A petition challenging this order under Art. 227

issues.text: Whether the High Court could interfere under Article 227 of the Constitution with the Authority's exercise of discretion in condoning the delay

anchor.surface_text: No appeal lies from an order of the Authority, under s. 20. But the High Court is vested with the power of judicial superintendence over the tribunal under Art. 227 of the Constitution. This power is number,greater than the power under Art. 226 and is limited to seeing that the tribunal functions within the limits of its authority

issues.text: Whether there was grave miscarriage of justice warranting interference by the Supreme Court under Article 136

anchor.surface_text: The Court cannot interfere merely because it might take a different view of the facts and exercise the discretion differently. it is number shown that the impugned order led to grave miscarriage of justice. The High Court refused to interfere under Art. 227. We think that this is number a fit case for interference by us under Art. 136.

holdings.text: The Authority has a discretion to condone the delay in presenting the application provided sufficient cause for the entire delay is shown to its satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: The Authority has a discretion to condone the delay in presenting the application provided sufficient cause for the entire delay is shown to its satisfaction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of second proviso to s. 20(2) Minimum Wages Act requiring satisfaction on sufficient cause for whole delay.

holdings.text: This discretion like other judicial discretion must be exercised with vigilance and circumspection according to justice, common sense, and sound judgment.

anchor.surface_text: This discretion like other judicial discretion must be exercised with vigilance and circumspection according to justice, common sense, and sound judgment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial discretion principles apply, citing Keighley's case.

holdings.text: The words sufficient cause in the second proviso to s. 20(2) should receive a similar liberal construction.

anchor.surface_text: the words sufficient cause receiving a liberal construction so as to advance substantial justice when no negligence no inaction no want of bona fides is imputable to the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to s.5 Limitation Act and precedents like Krishna v. Chathappan, approved in Dinabandhu Sahu and Ramlal v. Rewa Coalfields.

holdings.text: The High Court will not review the discretion of the Authority judicially exercised, but it may interfere if the exercise of the discretion is capricious or perverse or ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court is vested with the power of judicial superintendence over the tribunal under Art. 227 of the Constitution. This power is not greater than the power under Art. 226 and is limited to seeing that the tribunal functions within the limits of its authority

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited scope of Art. 227 superintendence, citing Nagendra Nath Bora; analogy to Payment of Wages Act in Sitaram Ramcharan.

holdings.text: Having regard to all the circumstances of the case, the employees were not guilty of inaction or negligence and the entire delay in presenting the application was due to their honest though mistaken belief that the relief of overtime wages would be granted to them through the intervention of the inspectors and their superior officers.

anchor.surface_text: The employees relied upon the assurances of the inspectors and their superiors that proper steps would, be taken for the remedy of their grievances and relying upon those assurances, they refrained from taking steps under s 20 2  of the Minimum.Wages Act Having regard to all the circumstances of the case, the employees were number guilty of inaction or negligence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts of complaints from Jan 1961, assurances by inspectors, reliance thereon show no negligence; inspectors have supervisory powers under s.19.

holdings.text: It is not shown that in condoning the delay the Authority acted, arbitrarily or capriciously or in excess of its jurisdiction or that it committed any error apparent on the face of the record.

anchor.surface_text: It is number shown that in companydoning the delay the Authority acted, arbitrarily or capriciously or in excess of its jurisdiction or that it companymitted any error apparent on the face of the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of perversity or ultra vires in Authority's careful consideration of materials.

holdings.text: The Authority declined to condone the delay in respect of claims for the period prior to January 1, 1961. On a careful consideration of the relevant materials, the Authority condoned the delay in respect of claims subsequent to January 1, 1961 only.

anchor.surface_text: In the application under 20 2  some of the employees claimed overtime wages for periods prior to January 1, 1961. The Authority declined to companydone the delay in respect of claims for the period prior to January 1, 1961.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Authority's fact-specific exercise of discretion upheld as non-arbitrary.

holdings.text: The Court cannot interfere merely because it might take a different view of the facts and exercise the discretion differently. it is not shown that the impugned order led to grave miscarriage of justice.

anchor.surface_text: The Court cannot interfere merely because it might take a different view of the facts and exercise the discretion differently. it is number shown that the impugned order led to grave miscarriage of justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No grave miscarriage; High Court correctly refused under Art.227.

holdings.text: We think that this is not a fit case for interference by us under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: We think that this is number a fit case for interference by us under Art. 136.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special leave appeal not warranting interference absent miscarriage of justice.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings lead to dismissal upholding Authority and High Court.
